headline: Clashes Continue in Maldives as the Former President Takes Part in a March
abstract: The Maldives is gripped by violent clashes between police and protesters in the wake of turmoil caused by the unexpected resignation of President Mohamed Nasheed, who was elected in 2008 in the countrys first democratic presidential election; his resignation has prompted claims and counterclaims about whether he was actually deposed in a coup; Nasheed implicates his successor, Mohamed Waheed Hassan, who had been vice president before being sworn into office as president.
snippet: Police and protesters faced off in the capital, Male, and the island nations former president said he was forced at gunpoint to resign this week.

headline: A Rustic Paradise, Open for Development
abstract: New zoning regulations will open Mexico's Guadalupe Valley to urban and suburban development, threatening character of rustic wine region; scientists say arid valley cannot sustain intensified development and many residents believe deal is part of familiar government corruption.

snippet: Peace will not come from a court case in a distant land. It must come from within.

abstract: Editorial criticizes India's Supreme Court for issuing a disgraceful ruling against human rights by reinstating law that bans gay sex; urges Prime Min Manmohan Singh's cabinet to immediately seek a repeal of the law.

headline: Individual Problems, Joint Solutions
abstract: Many couples about to marry share tales of what they have in common; there is also a special subset of couples whose bonds were forged in part by mutual obstacles, some quite serious, that they have agreed to face together.
snippet: For many couples, marriage is equal parts romance and support network. The way they confront joint obstacles like substance abuse or military deployment can affect their relationships.
subjects: Weddings and Engagements, Marriages

headline: Officials Say U.S. May Never Know Extent of Snowdens Leaks
abstract: American intelligence and law enforcement investigators conclude that they may never know full extent of classified documents extracted by former National Security Agency contractor Edward J Snowden; thwarted investigation, and Snowden's continued ability to hack into system and cover his tracks, illustrate how far computer security has lagged at America's intelligence agencies.
snippet: Investigators remain in the dark partly because the facility where the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden worked was not equipped with software to monitor employees.
subjects: Computer Security, News and News Media, United States International Relations, Classified Information and State Secrets, Surveillance of Citizens by Government

headline: Far Right in Eastern Europe Makes Gains as Syrians Arrive
abstract: Resurgence of far-right Ataka Party in Bulgaria illustrates how influx of Syrian refugees is fueling momentum of populist, anti-immigrant movements across Eastern Europe; group has used relatively small number of refugees to stoke fears and improve their fortunes in the European Union's poorest country.
snippet: A party known as Ataka, which means attack, champions Bulgaria for Bulgarians and has denounced Syrian refugees as terrorists whom Bulgaria, the European Unions poorest nation, must expel.
subjects: Discrimination, Immigration and Emigration, Elections, Refugees and Displaced Persons, Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

headline: Senate Asks C.I.A. to Share Its Report on Interrogations
abstract: Senate Intelligence Committee asks Central Intelligence Agency for an internal study that lawmakers believe is broadly critical of CIA's detention and interrogation program but was withheld from congressional oversight committees; request comes during yearlong battle with CIA over release of panels own exhaustive and highly critical report about the program, one of the most controversial policies of the post-September 11 era.
snippet: The Senate Intelligence Committee has asked the C.I.A. for an internal study that lawmakers believe is broadly critical of the C.I.A.s detention and interrogation program.

headline: Olympics Invite Trouble When Politics Drive Choices
abstract: Juliet Macur Sports Of The Times column argues that political furor surrounding the 2014 Sochi Olympic Games is entirely predictable, following long list of controversial Games in the past; holds that so long as the International Olympic Committee remains vulnerable to manipulation and influence of political figures, the Games will continue to be mired in debate about human rights rather than athleticism.
snippet: How have Olympians ended up in the middle of a human rights debate yet again?
subjects: Olympic Games (2014), Olympic Games, Human Rights and Human Rights Violations, Homosexuality, Discrimination

headline: Buoyed by a Deal With Russia, Ukraines Leader Tries to Reassert His Authority
abstract: Ukraine's Pres Viktor F Yanukovich moves on several fronts to reassert his domination after receiving what appears to be an economic lifeline in form of at least $15 billion in aid from Russia and a substantial reduction in price of Russian natural gas.
snippet: President Viktor F. Yanukovich repeated assurances that there would be no violent move to clear out antigovernment protesters in Kiev, yet also warned outside powers against interference.
subjects: International Trade and World Market, Embargoes and Economic Sanctions, International Relations

headline: U.N. Panel Cites Terror Campaign Against Syrian Civilians

headline: Putin, Secure in Power, Says He May Free Jailed Rival
abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin says Mikhail B Khodorkovsky, former oil tycoon and aspiring political rival, could soon be freed from prison; move is unexpected and a striking reversal of Putin's authoritarian rule, and many see it as an attempt to quiet critics before the Winter Olympics.
snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin said that Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former oil tycoon, could soon be freed from prison, a reversal many saw as an attempt to quiet critics before the Winter Olympics.

headline: Released Punk Rockers Keep Up Criticism of Putin
abstract: Maria Alyokhina and Nadezhda Tolokonnikova of the Russian punk band Pussy Riot are released from prison under a new amnesty law; women immediately seize on their sudden freedom to accuse Pres Vladimir V Putin of using the justice system to bolster his image before the Winter Olympics to be held in Sochi.
snippet: Critics said recent releases underscored the arbitrariness of the Russian justice system, as well as President Vladimir V. Putins singular authority.

headline: Democracy in Thailand
abstract: Editorial warns that Democrat Party protesters in Bangkok are playing a cynical and dangerous game by attempting to undermine call for early elections by Prime Min Yingluck Shinawatra; contends that group should instead participate in the election and offer proposals for the changes they think the country needs.
snippet: Efforts to block early elections by antigovernment protesters will lead to more unrest.
subjects: Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots, Editorials, Elections

headline: Amnesty by Russians Includes Greenpeace Case
abstract: Russia grants pardon to Anthony Perrett, member of the crew of Arctic Sunrise, Greenpeace International ship seized on the open seas in September 2013; amnesty is expected to be extended to rest of the crew, drawing to a close one of the more contentious chapters in the organizations history.
snippet: One member of a seized Greenpeace vessels crew received a pardon, and if the amnesty covers the rest, it will draw to a close one of the more contentious chapters in the organizations history.
subjects: Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots, Offshore Drilling and Exploration, Amnesties, Commutations and Pardons
